title: Treasury backs printing money over spending it
text:
Mr Beckett went on to suggest that if unconventional monetary policy was ineffective then fiscal policy could play a greater role.

When QE not working use fiscal

"Unconventional monetary policies are worthy of consideration when conventional space has been eroded, but they are somewhat less direct, can have larger wealth effects through asset prices and can be difficult

to unwind," Mr Beckett said.

"As such, fiscal policy can play a greater role when monetary policy is constrained."

However, all this was based on a situation where the economy had deteriorated much further.

"The RBA continues to emphasise QE as an option for a ‘worst case’ scenario where all major central banks are back at zero [per cent rates]," Mr Beckett included in the response.

This week Treasury Secretary Steven Kennedy told Senate estimates that monetary policy still remained a better response than fiscal stimulus to generate economic growth, but that Australia still needed more structural reform.

He said the situation that would warrant such fiscal stimulus were "uncommon" and that he saw see "the economy strengthening from here."

However the market expectations of when the Reserve Bank will use QE have risen.

In his testimony to a parliamentary economics committee in August, Dr Lowe said quantitative easing was "unlikely" but "possible".

"Given the world we're in, it is prudent to look at these things. As I said, it's unlikely, but it is possible."

In more detailed responses to questions in writing in September from the parliamentary economics committee chairman Tim Wilson, the RBA responded with detail on how effective QE could be for boosting employment and incomes.

"The first-order effect of quantitative easing is to increase incomes for households who would otherwise be unemployed," the central bank said.

AMP Capital's chief economist Shane Oliver said QE would be effective for the economy.

"Our assessment is that unconventional monetary policy measures may help in Australia, but it will depend on the measure deployed and their impact will be limited particularly compared to overseas," Dr Oliver said.

However, former RBA board member Warwick McKibbin has warned that unconventional monetary policy would wreck the financial system's allocation of capital and undermine capitalism.

The European Central Bank has already promised to restart its bond buying to the tune of €20 billion ($32.6 billion) a month.
description: New documents show Treasury advised the government that if the Reserve Bank of Australia opted for quantitative easing it would act as an alternative to a fiscal stimulus.
